Crime and Punishment

"I’ve been to a place with two floors of rooms owned by a merchant named Yushin."

"Yeah, rooms..."

"It’s a horrible place—dirty, smelly, and has a bad reputation. Bad things have happened there, and a lot of strange people live there. But it’s cheap..."

"I couldn’t find out much about it because I’m new to Petersburg," Pyotr Petrovitch said, a bit annoyed. "However, the two rooms are very clean, and since I’ll only be here for a short time... I’ve already rented a permanent place, our future flat," he said to Raskolnikov. "I’m having it fixed up. Right now, I’m cramped in a small room with my friend Andrey Semyonovitch Lebeziatnikov, at Madame Lippevechsel’s flat. He’s the one who told me about Bakaleyev’s house too..."

"Lebeziatnikov?" Raskolnikov said slowly, trying to remember something.

"Yes, Andrey Semyonovitch Lebeziatnikov, a clerk in the Ministry. Do you know him?"

"Yes... no," Raskolnikov replied.

"Sorry, I thought you did from your question. I was once his guardian... He’s a really nice young man and very modern. I enjoy meeting young people because you learn new things from them." Pyotr Petrovitch looked around hopefully at everyone.

"What do you mean?" Razumihin asked.
